{"step_by_step_thinking": "Autosomal dominant hypercholesterolemia type II is a genetic disorder characterized by very high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) due to a gene mutation causing premature coronary heart disease. The deficiency in this disorder is related to the LDL receptor. Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLR) gene cause 80% to 90% of cases of clinical familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) and have an autosomal dominant inheritance. Therefore, the correct answer is A. LDL receptor.", "answer_choice": "A"}
